title: Trump's Smart Play for African-Americans
summary: His share of the black vote in 2016 was respectable. Even a small increase could put him over the top.. If his State of the Union address and Super Bowl commercial are any indication, President Trump is serious about increasing his support among black voters in November. He may or may not succeed, but we're a long way from his cynical "What the hell do you have to lose?" pitch to blacks in 2016.

title: 'Chanel's Riviera' Review: It Takes a Villa
summary: A history of the Côte d'Azur, from the frivolity and decadence of its post-Jazz Age heyday to the terror and desperation of World War II.. La Pausa, Coco Chanel's stylish villa on the French Riviera, sat high on a ridge overlooking the curvy shoreline of Monaco, surrounded by olive trees and fragrant gardens. This is where Chanel at 47 tried to conceive a child with the fabulously wealthy Duke of Westminster, and where her next lover, the bookish illustrator Paul Iribe, fell dead of a heart attack while playing tennis on the villa's tree-shaded court. It was where Chanel entertained Winston Churchill and, later, her Nazi paramour Hans Günther von Dincklage. It was also where Jewish girls, posing as kitchen helpers during World War II, slipped out a back gate to a path in the mountains and eventually to safety, unbeknownst to the viscerally anti-Semitic Chanel.

title: Notable & Quotable: 'National Conservatism'
summary: 'We regard ourselves as direct descendants and rightful heirs of the Glorious Revolution of the 1980s.'. title: New York City Could Seize Cars of Drivers Racking Up Tickets
summary: Mayor expected to sign bill enforcing a safety-class requirement for those caught on camera. The New York City Council on Tuesday approved legislation creating the country's first traffic-enforcement program to seize cars of drivers who fail to take a safety class after racking up violations caught on camera.

title: Work Stoppages Reach Highest Level in Nearly Two Decades
summary: United Auto Workers' 40-day walkout at GM plants was largest strike started last year. Labor unrest reached its highest level in nearly two decades with 25 labor-related work stoppages-including strikes and lockouts-involving 1,000 or more workers in 2019, the Labor Department said Tuesday.

summary: The home-goods retailer cited product availability and lower store foot traffic as factors causing 'short-term pain'. Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. said same-store sales declined in December and January, as the company faces inventory challenges and issues attracting customers to its stores.

title: Bloomberg Reiterates Regret Over Stop-and-Frisk Practice
summary: The clip puts a fresh spotlight on the controversial practice as the former New York mayor tries to build support in the crowded Democratic presidential field. Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg apologized again Tuesday for supporting stop-and-frisk policing after audio of him aggressively defending it in 2015 was widely shared on social media.

title: Rocky Bankruptcy Debut for Company Tied to Fatal Blast at Houston Plant
summary: Bankruptcy judge rejects emergency financing, appoints committee to represent victims of last month's deadly industrial explosion. title: T-Mobile, Sprint Deal Wins Approval, Reshaping Industry
summary: Takeover will test whether three bigger carriers will compete as aggressively as four unequal players once did. A judge's approval of T-Mobile US Inc.'s takeover of Sprint Corp. will usher in a new balance of power in the U.S. wireless market and test whether three giants will compete as aggressively for cellphone users as four unequal players once did.

title: Undergrad's Father Lured Classmates into Cultlike Group, Authorities Say

summary: Bill heads to Senate where more stringent version of bill was withdrawn. Lawmakers in the Virginia House narrowly passed a bill banning assault-style weapons as Democrats continued using their newfound political clout to push ahead on a slate of gun-control bills.

summary: Drs. Borio and Gottlieb's plan deals only with the minority of coronavirus-infected persons who have accessed the health-care system.. The authors say: "First, doctors must be on high alert . . . The patient must also be showing symptoms . . . the people who show up at the hospital with pneumonia . . . Many major medical centers in the U.S. already have the capacity to run tests."

title: Toast Test: Are High-Tech Toasters Worth the Price?
summary: Do premium toasters-at premium prices-really yield a superior slice? We pitted six smart devices against a classic two-slice machine. THE CA-CHUNK of a triumphant toaster is one of the great All-American sounds. First sold in the 1890s, toasters predate even the advent of sliced bread, itself a response to a turn-of-the-century toasting craze. Most toasters do an adequate job, but since startup culture can't leave even the simplest devices alone, a new breed has popped up to disrupt the searing status quo.

title: The Democrats Gave In to Radicals and Gave Up on Common Sense
summary: Trump's personality and policies hastened the party's leftward shift, but it was a long time coming.. George Orwell noted the nervousness of people on the left when confronted by those even further to the left. This nervousness stems from leftists' fear that they will be taken for impure in their own leftism, that their thought and actions don't go far enough, that they are, finally, not really on the bus. In America during the 1930s, Communists mocked liberals for their weakness, and liberals worried about not measuring up. Hence the phenomenon of the "fellow traveler," someone who sympathized with the Communist Party but couldn't bring himself to join it.

title: Madison, Wisc.'s Real-Estate Market Gets an Epic Lift
summary: The healthcare software company in nearby Verona is drawing a young tech crowd to Wisconsin's capital city, which is known for its college town atmosphere and lakeside living. Sitting away from other major population centers, Madison, Wis., is a hidden Midwestern gem. Its downtown is between two lakes, Mendota and Monona, making Madison one of only two major U.S. cities built on an isthmus (the other is Seattle). With a population of about 260,000, its beating heart is a mix of the Wisconsin State Capitol and the University of Wisconsin-Madison, a combination that gives the town its unique personality. When it comes to residential real estate, the downtown market has been hot lately. One contributor has been the youthful, tech-centric staff at Epic, the health records software company located on a campus 11 miles south in Verona, one of 14 communities comprising greater Madison. But Madison's most expensive housing is in historic Maple Bluff. The roughly 1,300-person village has waterfront properties, bungalows and colonials, not to mention the 16,000-square-foot governor's residence.

title: The Pitfall to Avoid in Your Valentine's Day Cards
summary: Heed the advice of Nick D'Urbano and Cece de la Montagne, husband and wife founders of paper company Maurèle-who estimate they've filled 10 or 12 shoeboxes with love letters. After one week of dating, Nick D'Urbano decided to buy a pen for Cece de la Montagne. Writing has been essential to their relationship ever since. Sixteen years later, the now-married couple, both 33, live in Montreal with their baby and 10 to 12 shoeboxes filled with their love letters, which partly inspired them to launch a stationery company, Maurèle. "The first time Nick told me he loved me was through a letter," says de la Montagne. "I still appreciate the moments when I see his handwriting, because most of the time we're interacting with one another it's through text messages and emails."

The lodge launched Siwash Star Camp, two canvas tents set on a ridgetop platform deck with views of the lake and mountains. The tents are done in a traditional style, with patchwork quilts and antique furniture; the camp has a separate, heated washroom, an outdoor cedar hot tub, and loungers for stargazing like a pasha. Stays include meals sourced from the ranch's farm and surrounding wilderness, and activities such as horseback riding and river-rafting. From $4,450 per person for three nights, siwashlake.com

title: From a Refugee Camp to the Catwalk, a Top Model's Unusual Path
summary: Hailing from South Sudan by way of a Kenyan refugee camp and her family home in Adelaide, Australia, model Adut Akech has taken the fashion world by storm. A few years ago, drivers on a quiet street in Adelaide, Australia, might have come across a lone schoolgirl strutting back and forth on wedge heels, testing out her own private runway. Fast-forward to September 2016, when that same girl, in a gold dress, walks down the Saint Laurent catwalk in an 18th-century Parisian abbey. It's Adut Akech, who had practiced on that suburban street for years, making her debut on one of fashion's biggest stages.

title: Magazine Publisher Bonnier Explores Possible Sale of Main Media Unit
summary: Publisher of such magazines as Field & Stream, Saveur and Yachting, has been meeting with bankers to explore its options. Bonnier Corp., publisher of such magazines as Field & Stream, Saveur and Yachting, has been meeting with bankers to explore its options, including the possible sale of the unit that holds most of its magazines, according to people familiar with the situation.

title: Rutgers Is Actually Good at Basketball. No, Really.
summary: Picked to finish 12th in the Big Ten, the surprisingly resurgent Scarlet Knights are on track to make their first NCAA Tournament since 1991. In this jumbled season of college basketball, underdogs have pulled off massive upsets, decades-long winning streaks have snapped and the top teams are playing musical chairs with the No. 1 spot. The weird almost seems normal.

title: China Outbreak Weighs on Commodities, From Oil to Hogs
summary: Trade disruptions from coronavirus could be long lasting, analysts say, as stockpiles grow and ships lay idle. China's coronavirus outbreak has scrambled the global trade in commodities, hitting the country's massive appetite and challenging global supply lines set up to feed it.

title: China's Delivery Drivers Offer a Lifeline as They Brave Coronavirus Risk
summary: Online orders surge, but some quarantined residents are wary of what the couriers might bring. Forced to stay home during the coronavirus outbreak, many residents of the central Chinese metropolis of Wuhan rely on delivery drivers such as Zhang Hao, who risks infection himself as he zooms around the city by moped to deliver groceries and other supplies.

title: SoundCloud Gets $75 Million Investment From Sirius
summary: Satellite-radio giant takes minority stake, two board seats. SoundCloud Ltd. will take a $75 million shot in the arm from satellite-radio giant Sirius XM Holdings Inc. in exchange for a minority stake and two board seats at the audio-sharing platform, the companies said.

title: Stakes Run High for Mall Owner Trying to Save Forever 21
summary: Some other tenants could demand rent reductions or terminate their leases if vacancies remain. Analysts are split about whether Simon Property Group Inc.'s bid to rescue a distressed fast-fashion retailer will succeed, but even skeptics say the mall giant may have little choice but to salvage one of its most important tenants.

title: Beware of Wall Street's Armchair Epidemiologists
summary: Virus experts are far less confident about our ability to control the spread of coronavirus. Investors and analysts are racing to figure out how far the coronavirus outbreak will spread and what its eventual impact will be. Unfortunately, many are making assumptions that actual disease experts caution against. Some of Wall Street's reassuring statements about the epidemic could be wildly off, and so, too, their expectations of the economic disruption the virus could cause.

title: Many Private Equity-Backed Grocery Chains Buckle Under Debt and Pricing Pressure
summary: Fairway Market, Earth Fare are among stores that have filed for bankruptcy this year. The new world of online grocery sales and ultra-low-cost food staples is proving to be perilous for private-equity firms.

title: Companies Need to Dust Off Their No-Deal Brexit Plans
summary: The pound once again signals anxiety as the U.K. government seeks a loose trade deal with the EU that will mean more border checks. The U.K. has now left the European Union politically, but the more painful economic break is yet to come. Companies and investors still need to plan for a hard landing.

title: China's First Global Car Maker Is in the Works
summary: Resume Subscription. China may be about to get its first global car maker. Investors' initial reaction has been to celebrate the benefits rather than worry what it might cost them.

title: A Chinese College Nurtured a Sprawling Business Empire. Then Came a Debt Crisis.
summary: Prestigious Peking University has a problem: A conglomerate it owns most of has skidded very close to default. China's crushing debt burden is weighing on an unlikely place: one of its top universities.

title: Mind Those Manners: Kids Need Lessons in Email and Phone Etiquette
summary: When it comes to making calls and composing messages, a lack of social graces isn't something to LOL about. If the email addresses of Amanda McCraw's eighth-graders didn't contain some portion of their names, she would have no clue who the senders were.

title: Outdoor Retailer REI Building the Most Outdoorsy HQ Ever
summary: Company plans single site to consolidate offices near Seattle with a 'visual connection' to nature. In a Seattle suburb, retailer Recreational Equipment Inc. is building a new headquarters that is blurring the boundaries between office and nature.

title: Insurers Drive Up Prices on U.S. Businesses
summary: Large catastrophe losses and low interest rates force insurers' hand after years of no increases. U.S. companies are paying more for insurance, a reversal after years of flat or declining rates for property and liability policies.

title: New Hampshire Primary 2020: What Time Polls Close and When to Expect Results
summary: New Hampshire primary results come on the heels of messy Iowa caucuses. Here's how to follow WSJ's coverage.. New Hampshire voters will turn out for the first-in-the-nation primary, days after the chaotic Iowa caucuses, which were marred by several days of delay in reporting the full results.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: China Fires Highest-Level Officials Yet Over Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: Beijing replaced two provincial health officials in charge of virus-racked Hubei province with a trusted official from national health agency. HONG KONG-Beijing fired the highest-ranking officials yet over the handling of the coronavirus outbreak, replacing two provincial health officials in charge of virus-racked Hubei province with a trusted official from China's national health agency.

title: Prosecutors Seek up to Nine Years in Prison for Ex-Trump Adviser Stone
summary: Stone, found guilty of witness tampering, obstruction of a congressional proceeding and lying to Congress, is to be sentenced next week. WASHINGTON-Prosecutors recommended that longtime Trump adviser Roger Stone receive seven to nine years in prison on charges related to his efforts to make contact with WikiLeaks during the 2016 presidential campaign, in what could be the longest sentence to stem from the special counsel's investigation.

title: Trump Rallies in New Hampshire Ahead of Primary
summary: President encourages his supporters to vote in the state's Democratic contest. MANCHESTER, N.H.-President Trump encouraged his supporters to vote in New Hampshire's Democratic primary, urging a rally crowd in Manchester on Monday to cast a ballot for whoever would be easiest for him to beat.

title: 'Parasite' Financial Backer Started as a Food Maker
summary: Seoul-based CJ Group also focuses on K-Pop music groups and invested in DreamWorks. LOS ANGELES-"Parasite" dominated the 92nd Academy Awards thanks in large part to the financial backing of a nearly seven-decade-old conglomerate that is little known in the U.S. but looms large in the South Korea media-and-entertainment business.

title: Wuhan Evacuees Hunker Down for Weeks in Quarantine
summary: China's shutdown of the city was unprecedented. So is the evacuation and quarantine of hundreds of Americans fleeing the outbreak's epicenter.. Tennessee resident David Mayes was in China visiting his girlfriend in Wuhan when officials locked down the city on Jan. 23, aiming to stop a rapidly spreading coronavirus that has killed hundreds there.

title: China's Businesses Struggle to Resume Work
summary: Operations are slow to restart, with many workers unable to reach factories or offices and supply chains disrupted. Business was slow to restart in China, even after some local governments stopped calling for people to stay away from the workplace during a coronavirus outbreak that has killed more than 1,000 people in the country and dented economic growth.

title: President Xi Inspects Coronavirus Hospital in Beijing
summary: Chinese leader acknowledges that some medical workers had 'sacrificed their lives' in fight against epidemic. BEIJING-Chinese President Xi Jinping paid his first public visit to the front lines of the coronavirus outbreak, stopping at a Beijing hospital treating infected patients and at a local disease-control office after weeks of remaining largely out of public view.

title: Federal Judge Expected to Clear Way for T-Mobile and Sprint Merger
summary: Decision on marriage of No. 3 and No. 4 U.S. carriers is poised to reshape wireless industry. A federal judge is expected to approve T-Mobile US Inc.'s merger with Sprint Corp., according to people familiar with the matter, clearing the way for the two wireless rivals to combine and overcoming a state antitrust challenge.

title: Justice Department Files Lawsuits Over Sanctuary Policies
summary: Lawsuits target laws and policies limiting local cooperation with Immigration and Customs Enforcement. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department sued New Jersey and a Washington county Monday over their laws and policies limiting local cooperation with Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

title: Former IHS Doctor Sentenced to Five Lifetime Terms for Sexually Abusing Boys
summary: Former Indian Health Service pediatrician Stanley Patrick Weber abused patients in Montana and South Dakota between 1995 and 2011. RAPID CITY, S.D.-An Indian Health Service pediatrician who was convicted of sexually abusing young Native American boys in his care over two decades and became an emblem of the federal agency's long-term failures was sentenced Monday to five lifetime prison terms.

title: Trump Deficit Forecast Is Built on Shaky Assumptions, Experts Say
summary: Proposed $4.8 trillion budget assumes greater-than-expected economic growth and overlooks potential tax-law changes. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration's proposed budget projects federal deficits would be cut in half as a share of the economy by 2024, and in half again by 2029. While White House officials say they are serious about fulfilling President Trump's promise to reduce swelling deficits, budget experts say the projections are built on questionable assumptions.

title: Private Equity-Backed PCI Pharma Services Weighs a Sale
summary: PCI Pharma Services is being marketed heavily to private-equity buyers. Private equity-backed PCI Pharma Services is looking for a new owner, preferably another buyout firm.

title: Better Pipes for Safer Oil Transport
summary: Minnesota regulators approve a greener way to move fossil fuels.. Climate-change activists want to ban fossil fuels, and that means opposing all pipelines that move oil from producers to the market. Green activists succeeded in delaying Enbridge's Line 3 in the Upper Midwest for more than a year, but last week the oil pipeline cleared a key regulatory hurdle. That's good news for the environment.

title: Professional Budget Wrestling
summary: Friday Night SmackDown offers more sincerity than the Beltway spending theatrics.. The White House released its 2021 fiscal year budget proposal on Monday, and it's amusing to hear those who have criticized the Trump Administration for trillion-dollar deficits now howl about its plans to slow spending growth. A bipartisan spending blowout is the reality in the Trump era, while the budget is a political document that probably wouldn't happen even if the President wins a second term.

title: Mini-Merkel's Mega Meltdown
summary: German conservatives head for a welcome new leadership race.. German politics was thrown into new turmoil Monday when Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, leader of the center-right Christian Democratic Union, announced she won't run for Chancellor next year. The defense minister, known as AKK, was Chancellor Angela Merkel's preferred successor.

title: Currency Manipulator in Chief
summary: Wilbur Ross creates a new political opening for U.S. protectionism.. The Commerce Department last week announced a regulation that will allow new tariffs on "products that benefit from unfair currency subsidies." Does that mean Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross is going to slap tariffs on the White House?

title: How a Reality-TV Producer Became Rainmaker to $300 Billion Saudi Fund
summary: Resume Subscription. RIYADH-Businesses looking for cash from Saudi Arabia's $300 billion sovereign-wealth fund, one of the world's most influential investors, have found it helps to enlist a former reality-TV producer from Sarasota, Fla.

title: Democrats Want a Prophet, Not a President
summary: They're increasingly rigid and orthodox, even as Republicans have shown a new flexibility.. The Democrats have turned religious. Not in the sense that they espouse a belief in an omnipotent and benevolent Creator or eternal and universal moral principles. They are religious in the sense that they hold dogmatic beliefs that are impervious to contradiction by logic, evidence or experience, and cultivate a moral superiority toward unbelievers. The party that loudly prides itself on tolerance and diversity is increasingly intolerant in at least three areas.

title: Medicare for All Could Mean Doctors for None
summary: Under single-payer, drastic pay cuts for physicians would drive sharp young people into other, more lucrative fields.. Professional groups representing doctors are buying into Democratic plans to remake health care-and thereby acting against the interests of their members. The American College of Physicians, the second-largest organization of U.S. doctors, recently came out in support of either a public option or single payer. At the American Medical Association's annual meeting last year, some 47% of delegates voted to reverse the organization's opposition to single payer. A new organization styling itself Physicians for a National Health Program has attracted some 20,000 members.
